title: Ezekiel Chapter 37 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 37 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 37 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 37.

questions.question: Where did the spirit of the LORD set Ezekiel down in Ezekiel 37?
options: In the midst of a valley full of bones
On a mountain
By the river
In a desert
questions.correctAnswer: In the midst of a valley full of bones
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:1 states that the hand of the LORD carried Ezekiel and set him down in the midst of the valley which was full of bones.

questions.question: What was Ezekiel commanded to do to the dry bones?
options: Prophesy upon them
Burn them
Ignore them
Build a wall around them
questions.correctAnswer: Prophesy upon them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:4 records that God told Ezekiel to prophesy upon the dry bones and say the word of the LORD to them.

questions.question: What happened when Ezekiel prophesied to the bones as commanded?
options: There was a noise, a shaking, and the bones came together bone to bone
The bones disappeared
The bones turned into stones
The bones were covered with dust
questions.correctAnswer: There was a noise, a shaking, and the bones came together bone to bone
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:7 describes that as Ezekiel prophesied, there was a noise and shaking, and the bones came together bone to bone.

questions.question: What was still missing from the bones after sinews, flesh, and skin covered them?
options: Breath
Eyes
Blood
Hair
questions.correctAnswer: Breath
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:8 explains that although sinews, flesh, and skin covered the bones, there was no breath in them.

questions.question: To what did God tell Ezekiel to prophesy in order to bring breath into the slain?
options: The wind
The sun
The fire
The water
questions.correctAnswer: The wind
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:9 commands Ezekiel to prophesy to the wind (breath) to come from the four winds and breathe upon the slain so they may live.

questions.question: What did the dry bones become after the breath came into them?
options: An exceeding great army
A small group of people
A flock of birds
A river of water
questions.correctAnswer: An exceeding great army
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:10 states that the breath came into the bones, and they lived and stood up upon their feet as an exceeding great army.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 37, what do the dry bones represent?
options: The whole house of Israel
The nations of the world
The angels in heaven
The kings of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: The whole house of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:11 explains that the dry bones represent the whole house of Israel who say their bones are dried and hope is lost.

questions.question: What will God do to His people according to Ezekiel 37:12?
options: Open their graves and bring them into the land of Israel
Send them into exile forever
Make them kings over all nations
Build a temple for them in Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Open their graves and bring them into the land of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:12 says God will open the graves of His people and cause them to come up and be brought into the land of Israel.

questions.question: What will God put in His people so they shall live, according to Ezekiel 37?
options: His spirit
His treasure
His laws
His angels
questions.correctAnswer: His spirit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:14 states that God will put His spirit in His people and they shall live.

questions.question: What were the two sticks Ezekiel was told to write on and join together?
options: For Judah and for Joseph, the stick of Ephraim
For Israel and for Egypt
For Babylon and for Assyria
For David and for Solomon
questions.correctAnswer: For Judah and for Joseph, the stick of Ephraim
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:16 instructs Ezekiel to take one stick and write on it for Judah and his companions, and another for Joseph, the stick of Ephraim, and his companions.

questions.question: What will happen to the sticks in Ezekiel's hand after he joins them?
options: They shall become one stick
They shall break into pieces
They will vanish
They will turn into gold
questions.correctAnswer: They shall become one stick
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:17 states that after joining the sticks, they shall become one in Ezekiel's hand.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 37:22 says one king shall rule over the united nation of Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:22 clearly states that one king shall be king to them all when they become one nation.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 37:23, the people will continue to defile themselves with idols after being saved.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:23 says they shall no longer defile themselves with idols but will be saved and cleansed by God.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 37:27 declares that God's tabernacle shall be with the people forevermore.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:27 states that God's tabernacle shall be with them, and He will be their God forevermore.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezekiel 37:25: 'And they shall dwell in the land that I have given unto Jacob my servant, wherein your fathers have dwelt; and they shall dwell therein, even they, and their ______, and their children's children for ever.'
options: children
friends
enemies
neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: children
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:25 states that they and their children and their children's children shall dwell in the land forever.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 37 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 37 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement and feels spiritually dry. Based on Ezekiel 37, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God's power to restore life?
options: God can breathe life into what seems dead and hopeless
We must rely solely on our own strength to revive our spirit
Physical effort alone can restore spiritual vitality
Ignoring feelings of dryness is the best approach
questions.correctAnswer: God can breathe life into what seems dead and hopeless
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:1-10 describes dry bones coming to life by God's breath, showing that God can restore spiritual life and hope even when things seem hopeless. Trusting God's power rather than self-effort is the key (verses 5, 6, 9, 10).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 37 teach us about obedience and faith when facing difficult spiritual challenges?
options: Obey God's commands even when the outcome seems impossible
Only obey God when results are guaranteed
Faith is unnecessary if we do our best
Doubt is a sign to stop obeying
questions.correctAnswer: Obey God's commands even when the outcome seems impossible
questions.explanation: Ezekiel prophesied to the dry bones as commanded, despite their lifeless state, and witnessed God's miraculous work (37:4-7). This teaches obedience and faith in God's promises even in difficult situations (37:3, 10).

questions.question: A believer feels cut off and without hope. What practical encouragement from Ezekiel 37 can you share about God’s promise for restoration?
options: God promises to open graves and bring His people back to life
Hopelessness means God has abandoned us
We must earn God's favor to be restored
Restoration is only for a select few
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to open graves and bring His people back to life
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:11-14 speaks to Israel’s despair but assures that God will open their graves and put His Spirit within them, restoring life and hope. This encourages trusting God’s faithful restoration rather than despair.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 37 illustrate the importance of spiritual unity in the church and family of believers?
options: God will join divided groups into one unified people
Division among believers is unavoidable and not addressed by God
Unity is only a human responsibility, not God’s work
Individualism is preferred over unity
questions.correctAnswer: God will join divided groups into one unified people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:15-22 shows God’s promise to join the stick of Judah with the stick of Joseph, symbolizing uniting the divided tribes of Israel into one nation, teaching the value of spiritual unity among God’s people.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 37 teach about God’s role in cleansing and renewing His people after sin?
options: God promises to save, cleanse, and make His people His own
People must cleanse themselves without God's help
Sin cannot be forgiven once it happens
God ignores sin and does not address it
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to save, cleanse, and make His people His own
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:23 explains that God will save His people from their sins, cleanse them, and make them His people, teaching that God takes initiative in spiritual renewal and forgiveness.

questions.question: How can Ezekiel 37 encourage believers to persevere through spiritual trials and discouragement?
options: God’s Spirit can bring life and hope even when circumstances look bleak
Trials mean God has forgotten us
Discouragement should end all spiritual efforts
Only human effort can overcome trials
questions.correctAnswer: God’s Spirit can bring life and hope even when circumstances look bleak
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:14 promises that God will put His Spirit in His people so they shall live, encouraging believers to rely on God’s Spirit for perseverance through trials and discouragement.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 37 shows that God’s promises of restoration depend entirely on human effort and ability.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The chapter emphasizes God’s power to restore life and unity by His Spirit, not by human ability alone (Ezekiel 37:5, 9, 14). Human obedience is important, but restoration comes from God’s action.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 37 teaches that God will place His sanctuary and dwell among His people forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:26-27 promises an everlasting covenant and that God’s tabernacle will be with His people forever, indicating His ongoing presence and fellowship with them.

questions.question: When a believer feels spiritually dry, Ezekiel 37 encourages us to ________________.
options: trust God to breathe new life into us
ignore our feelings and continue as usual
depend on our own strength only
avoid thinking about restoration
questions.correctAnswer: trust God to breathe new life into us
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:5-6 and 9-10 show that God breathes life into dry bones, symbolizing His power to restore spiritual vitality when we trust Him.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 37, what is a key sign of God’s restoration and blessing on His people’s lives?
options: They will live in their own land with one king and one shepherd
They will be separated into many nations
They will rely only on idols
They will forsake God’s statutes
questions.correctAnswer: They will live in their own land with one king and one shepherd
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:22-24 describes God’s promise to unify His people under one king and shepherd, living in their land, which symbolizes restoration and blessing.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 37 encourage believers to maintain integrity and obedience in daily life?
options: By walking in God's judgments and observing His statutes
By ignoring God's laws when inconvenient
By doing what seems right in their own eyes
By following only cultural customs
questions.correctAnswer: By walking in God's judgments and observing His statutes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:24 teaches that God’s people shall walk in His judgments and observe His statutes, emphasizing the importance of obedience and integrity in daily living.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 37 say about God’s covenant with His people after their restoration?
options: It is an everlasting covenant of peace
It is temporary and conditional
It depends on human merit
It is only for a select few
questions.correctAnswer: It is an everlasting covenant of peace
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:26 declares God will make an everlasting covenant of peace with His people, showing His enduring commitment to them.

questions.question: A believer asks how to respond to division in the church. Based on Ezekiel 37, what biblical principle would you share?
options: God desires to unite His people into one body
Division is a sign that God is displeased
Separation is the best way to maintain peace
Unification is impossible
questions.correctAnswer: God desires to unite His people into one body
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:19-20 shows God’s plan to unite the divided tribes into one nation, teaching that unity in the church is God’s will.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 37 illustrate the role of the Holy Spirit in the believer’s life?
options: God puts His Spirit in people to give them life and renewal
The Spirit is irrelevant to spiritual life
The Spirit only works in Old Testament times
The Spirit depends on human effort to act
questions.correctAnswer: God puts His Spirit in people to give them life and renewal
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:14 explains that God will put His Spirit in His people so they shall live, emphasizing the vital role of the Holy Spirit in spiritual renewal.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and prophetic speaking can we learn from Ezekiel 37?
options: Obediently proclaiming God’s word can bring spiritual transformation
Prayer is unnecessary if we act alone
Speaking God’s word has no power
Prophesying is only for special leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Obediently proclaiming God’s word can bring spiritual transformation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:4-10 shows that when Ezekiel obeyed God’s command to prophesy to the bones and the wind, a miraculous transformation occurred, teaching the power of prayerful obedience.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 37 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 37.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 37, what is the significance of the valley full of dry bones that the prophet is set down in?
options: A representation of the whole house of Israel in a state of spiritual death
A vision of the nations surrounding Israel in conflict
A prophecy about the destruction of Jerusalem
A symbolic depiction of the temple's destruction
questions.correctAnswer: A representation of the whole house of Israel in a state of spiritual death
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:11 explains that the dry bones represent the whole house of Israel, who feel their hope is lost and they are cut off.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Ezekiel 37 with the valley of dry bones coming to life?
options: Typology illustrating spiritual resurrection
Parable illustrating wisdom
Allegory of political unification
Prophetic lamentation
questions.correctAnswer: Typology illustrating spiritual resurrection
questions.explanation: The vision uses typology to foreshadow Israel's restoration and spiritual revival, as seen in verses 5-6 where breath enters the bones bringing them to life.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most directly references the theme of spiritual resurrection found in Ezekiel 37?
options: John 11:25-26, where Jesus speaks of being the resurrection and the life
Romans 12:1, urging believers to present their bodies as a living sacrifice
Matthew 24:30, about the coming of the Son of Man
Acts 2:38, on repentance and baptism
questions.correctAnswer: John 11:25-26, where Jesus speaks of being the resurrection and the life
questions.explanation: John 11:25-26 echoes the theme of bringing life from death, paralleling Ezekiel's vision of dry bones revived by God's breath.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the Hebrew word translated as 'breath' in Ezekiel 37:5 and 9, and why is it significant?
options: Ruach, meaning spirit or wind, signifying God's life-giving power
Shema, meaning to hear, emphasizing obedience
Chesed, meaning lovingkindness, highlighting God's mercy
Mishpat, meaning judgment, indicating divine justice
questions.correctAnswer: Ruach, meaning spirit or wind, signifying God's life-giving power
questions.explanation: The Hebrew 'ruach' in this context indicates God's spirit or breath that animates and gives life, a central theme in Ezekiel 37:5 and 9.

questions.question: How does the act of joining two sticks in Ezekiel 37:16-17 symbolize Israel’s future?
options: The reunification of the divided kingdoms of Israel and Judah into one nation
A political alliance between Israel and neighboring nations
The binding of a treaty with Egypt
The separation of Israel from pagan influences
questions.correctAnswer: The reunification of the divided kingdoms of Israel and Judah into one nation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:19 explains the joining of the sticks symbolizes God’s promise to reunite the northern kingdom (Joseph/Ephraim) and southern kingdom (Judah).

questions.question: What historical context underlies Ezekiel’s vision of the dry bones and the reunification of sticks?
options: The Babylonian exile and the division of the Israelite nation
The conquest of Canaan by Joshua
The Assyrian invasion of Israel
The rebuilding of the Second Temple
questions.correctAnswer: The Babylonian exile and the division of the Israelite nation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel prophesied during the Babylonian exile, when Israel was in despair and divided, as reflected in the imagery of dry bones and separated sticks.

questions.question: Which Old Testament king is mentioned in Ezekiel 37 as the future king who will reign over the united nation?
options: David
Solomon
Hezekiah
Josiah
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:24-25 refers to David as the servant who will be king over the reunited Israel, indicating a Messianic hope.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel’s vision in chapter 37 promises that the people will never again defile themselves with idols or transgressions after their restoration.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:23 promises cleansing from sin and idols, so the people will be God’s people without defilement after restoration.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'I will put my spirit in you, and ye shall live' in Ezekiel 37:14 foreshadow in the broader biblical narrative?
options: The New Testament promise of the Holy Spirit’s indwelling in believers
The building of Solomon’s temple
The destruction of Jerusalem
The calling of the first prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The New Testament promise of the Holy Spirit’s indwelling in believers
questions.explanation: This promise anticipates the New Testament teaching of God’s Spirit giving life and renewal, as in Acts and Pauline epistles.

questions.question: Which literary structure can be observed in the sequence of Ezekiel 37:1-14 concerning the dry bones vision?
options: Chiasm, with the bones starting lifeless and ending alive with God’s spirit
Parallelism, repeating the same phrase with slight variation
Acrostic, using sequential Hebrew letters
Allegory, representing political events
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, with the bones starting lifeless and ending alive with God’s spirit
questions.explanation: The narrative forms a chiasm, moving from death (dry bones) to life (breath/spirit entering), highlighting God’s power to restore.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'the sticks whereon thou writest shall be in thine hand before their eyes' in Ezekiel 37:20 imply about the prophetic sign act?
options: The prophecy is a visible sign to the people to demonstrate God’s promise
The sticks are hidden symbols only understood by the prophet
It signifies the destruction of the sticks as judgment
It indicates a secret covenant between nations
questions.correctAnswer: The prophecy is a visible sign to the people to demonstrate God’s promise
questions.explanation: The sign act of holding the sticks visibly communicates the message of national reunification to Israel, as stated in verse 20.

questions.question: Which theme in Ezekiel 37 connects to the covenant theology seen earlier in the Old Testament?
options: The everlasting covenant of peace established by God with Israel
The conditional blessings of Deuteronomy
The Mosaic law given at Sinai
The Abrahamic promise of many descendants
questions.correctAnswer: The everlasting covenant of peace established by God with Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:26 speaks of an everlasting covenant of peace, echoing covenant themes throughout Old Testament history.

questions.question: How does the cultural context of ancient Near Eastern kingship enhance understanding of Ezekiel 37:24’s reference to David as king and shepherd?
options: Kings were viewed as shepherds, caretakers responsible for justice and welfare of their people
Kings were primarily military commanders with no spiritual role
Kings were isolated from their subjects and ruled through governors
Kingship was symbolic and not related to daily life
questions.correctAnswer: Kings were viewed as shepherds, caretakers responsible for justice and welfare of their people
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, kings were often described as shepherds, a metaphor for their protective and guiding role, as in Ezekiel 37:24.

questions.question: The phrase 'My tabernacle also shall be with them' in Ezekiel 37:27 alludes to what significant biblical theme?
options: God’s presence dwelling among His people permanently
The establishment of a new temple in Babylon
The destruction of the tabernacle in the wilderness
The exile of the Levites
questions.correctAnswer: God’s presence dwelling among His people permanently
questions.explanation: This verse promises God's enduring presence with Israel, recalling the tabernacle as a symbol of God dwelling with His people.

questions.question: Which element of Ezekiel 37 foreshadows the Messianic expectation fulfilled in the New Testament?
options: The promise of one king over the reunited nation, linked to David
The physical resurrection of the dry bones as a literal event
The building of a political empire in exile
The defeat of foreign nations by military might
questions.correctAnswer: The promise of one king over the reunited nation, linked to David
questions.explanation: The prophecy about David as king (Ezekiel 37:24-25) anticipates the Messiah who would unite and reign over God's people, fulfilled in Christ.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 37 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 37 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary symbolic meaning of the dry bones in Ezekiel's vision?
options: The whole house of Israel, representing their spiritual death and hope lost
The Gentile nations scattered among the peoples
The leaders of Judah and Israel divided in judgment
The temple and its defilement by idols
questions.correctAnswer: The whole house of Israel, representing their spiritual death and hope lost
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:11 explicitly identifies the dry bones as the whole house of Israel who say their bones are dried and hope is lost. This symbolizes spiritual death, exile, and despair. This theme is consistent with resurrection imagery in John 5:28-29, Romans 11:25-26, and the restoration hope in Jeremiah 31:31-34.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 37, what divine action causes the dry bones to live?
options: The breath (spirit) of God entering them
A mighty earthquake shaking the valley
The sound of a trumpet summoning them
The prophesying of Ezekiel alone without divine breath
questions.correctAnswer: The breath (spirit) of God entering them
questions.explanation: Verses 5, 6, 9, and 10 highlight that God causes breath to enter the bones, causing them to live. This breath represents the Spirit of God (pneumatology) giving life, paralleling Genesis 2:7 where God breathes life into man, and John 20:22 where Jesus breathes the Holy Spirit on the disciples.

questions.question: What covenantal promise is made concerning the restored people in Ezekiel 37?
options: An everlasting covenant of peace with God dwelling among them
A temporary alliance with foreign nations
A covenant of strict legalism without mercy
A promise of earthly riches and political power alone
questions.correctAnswer: An everlasting covenant of peace with God dwelling among them
questions.explanation: Verse 26 speaks of an everlasting covenant of peace with God placing His sanctuary among them forever, signifying God's enduring presence and relationship, consistent with the new covenant promises in Jeremiah 31:31-34, Hebrews 8:6-13, and Revelation 21:3.

questions.question: The joining of the two sticks representing Judah and Joseph symbolizes what future event?
options: The reunification of Israel into one nation under one king
The permanent division of the northern and southern kingdoms
The destruction of Israel by foreign powers
The scattering of Israel among the nations
questions.correctAnswer: The reunification of Israel into one nation under one king
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 37:16-17 and 19-22 describe the joining of the sticks to symbolize the reunification of Israel and Judah into one nation with one king, foreshadowing messianic unity as in Isaiah 11:13-16, Jeremiah 3:18, and the New Testament fulfillment in Ephesians 2:14-16.

questions.question: Who is identified as the future king over the reunited nation in Ezekiel 37?
options: David, God’s servant
Solomon, known for wisdom
Saul, the first king of Israel
Jeroboam, the northern king
questions.correctAnswer: David, God’s servant
questions.explanation: Verses 24 and 25 refer to David, God’s servant, as king over the reunited people, indicating a messianic prophecy fulfilled ultimately in Christ as the Son of David (Luke 1:32, Acts 2:30, Revelation 22:16), emphasizing Christological continuity.

questions.question: What role does the Spirit of God play in the restoration of Israel in Ezekiel 37?
options: It is the life-giving breath that resurrects and revives the people
It convicts the people of their sins without restoring them
It leads the people into exile permanently
It judges the nations without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: It is the life-giving breath that resurrects and revives the people
questions.explanation: Verse 14 speaks of God putting His Spirit in the people so they shall live, revealing the Spirit’s role in spiritual resurrection and renewal, consistent with Ezekiel 36:26-27, Romans 8:11, and Titus 3:5.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'valley full of bones' in the context of Israel’s condition?
options: It represents Israel’s hopelessness and spiritual death in exile
It is a literal valley filled with dead soldiers
It symbolizes the wealth of the land of Israel
It represents the temple courts defiled by idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: It represents Israel’s hopelessness and spiritual death in exile
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 describe the valley full of very dry bones symbolizing Israel’s hopeless and lifeless condition in exile, paralleling themes of spiritual death in Psalm 143:7-10, Isaiah 61:1-3, and John 11:25.

questions.question: What does God promise will happen when He opens the graves of the people of Israel?
options: They will come up out of their graves and live in their own land
They will be judged and condemned for their sins
They will be scattered further among the nations
They will build a new temple but remain in exile
questions.correctAnswer: They will come up out of their graves and live in their own land
questions.explanation: Verses 12-13 promise that God will open their graves, bring them up, and place them in their land, indicating physical and spiritual restoration, consistent with resurrection hope in Daniel 12:2, Isaiah 26:19, and John 5:28-29.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 37 depict God's holiness in relation to Israel’s restoration?
options: God sanctifies Israel and sets His sanctuary in their midst forever
God remains distant and indifferent to Israel’s sins
God allows idols to remain among the people
God punishes Israel without offering restoration
questions.correctAnswer: God sanctifies Israel and sets His sanctuary in their midst forever
questions.explanation: Verse 28 declares that God sanctifies Israel and establishes His sanctuary among them forever, showing His holiness and desire for fellowship, aligning with Leviticus 20:7-8, 2 Corinthians 6:16, and Revelation 21:22-27.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 37 teach about the nature of sin and its removal in the restored nation?
options: Sin and idolatry will be removed; God will cleanse them to be His people
Sin will continue but be tolerated by God
Idolatry will be replaced with other false religions
Sin will increase as a test of faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Sin and idolatry will be removed; God will cleanse them to be His people
questions.explanation: Verse 23 states that the people will no longer defile themselves with idols or sins; God will cleanse them, making them His people, consistent with Isaiah 1:18, Hebrews 10:10, and 1 John 1:7-9 regarding sanctification and forgiveness.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 37, what does the phrase 'one king shall be king to them all' imply about the future governance of Israel?
options: A messianic monarchy under a single sovereign
A confederation with multiple tribal leaders
A democracy with equal political power among tribes
Rule by foreign kings as a punishment
questions.correctAnswer: A messianic monarchy under a single sovereign
questions.explanation: Verse 22 promises one king to rule over the reunited nation, implying messianic kingship typified by Christ as prophesied in Psalm 2 and Zechariah 9:9, fulfilled in the New Testament (Luke 1:32-33, Revelation 19:16).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel respond when commanded to prophesy to the dry bones?
options: He obeys and prophesies as commanded
He refuses out of fear
He questions God’s command openly
He ignores the command
questions.correctAnswer: He obeys and prophesies as commanded
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states Ezekiel prophesied as commanded, showing obedience and trust in God’s word, illustrating prophetic ministry examples like Isaiah 6:8-9 and Jeremiah 1:7-10.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'breath' or 'wind' that Ezekiel is told to prophesy to in Ezekiel 37:9?
options: It represents the Spirit of God bringing life to the slain
It is the natural wind that dries the bones
It symbolizes the nations attacking Israel
It signifies the breath of human effort to restore Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It represents the Spirit of God bringing life to the slain
questions.explanation: Verse 9 commands Ezekiel to prophesy to the wind (Hebrew 'ruach'), symbolizing the Spirit of God breathing life, consistent with pneumatology in Genesis 1:2, Job 33:4, and John 3:8.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 37 illustrate the relationship between prophecy and divine action?
options: Prophecy is a means God uses to bring about resurrection and restoration
Prophecy is a human invention without real effect
Divine action occurs independently of prophetic words
Prophecy only warns of judgment without hope
questions.correctAnswer: Prophecy is a means God uses to bring about resurrection and restoration
questions.explanation: Ezekiel prophesies to the bones and wind (37:4-10), and God uses these words to effect resurrection, showing prophecy’s efficacy, paralleling Isaiah 55:11, 2 Kings 22:14-20, and Acts 2:17-21.

questions.question: What does the imagery of the bones coming together, sinews and flesh forming, but no breath yet, teach about spiritual restoration?
options: Physical restoration precedes spiritual revival, which requires God’s breath (Spirit)
Physical restoration alone is sufficient for full life
Spiritual restoration occurs without any physical change
Restoration is only symbolic and not real
questions.correctAnswer: Physical restoration precedes spiritual revival, which requires God’s breath (Spirit)
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 depict physical reassembly without breath, indicating that full life requires God’s Spirit, consistent with Ezekiel 36:26-27, Romans 8:11, and John 20:22 teaching the necessity of the Spirit for true life.
